message_1: Suppose a logistic map is defined as x(n+1) = r * x(n) * (1 - x(n)), where x(0) = 0.5 and r = 3.7. Use the period-doubling route to chaos to determine the period of the system after the first bifurcation.
message_2:
The period-doubling route to chaos in a logistic map occurs when the parameter r increases, causing the system to undergo a series of bifurcations, each of which doubles the period of the system. 

Initially, the logistic map has a period of 1 (i.e., it converges to a fixed point). The first bifurcation occurs when r crosses the value of 3. At this point, the system's period doubles from 1 to 2. 

In our case, since r = 3.7, which is greater than 3, the system has already undergone the first bifurcation. Therefore, the period of the system after the first bifurcation is 2.
